text.p: These are the highlights of the main Sao Paulo and Rio de Janeiro newspapers this morning.
GAZETA MERCANTIL
-- ACESITA'S MARKET VALUE DROPS 59.4 PCT

The preferred shares of private steel mill Acesita have fallen 59.4 percent so far this year, while the steel sector has risen 11.6 percent. The drop is partially attributed to the strategy of expansion and diversification designed by the firm's president Wilson Brumer.
-- EMBRAER EXPORTS $375 MLN
Continental Express Inc, a unit of Continental Airlines Inc, announced it placed a five-year order for 25 Embraer EMB-145 50-seat regional jets, valued at $375 million.
-- PAOLI LIKELY TO LEAVE MAPPIN
Pacifico Paoli will leave his post at department store chain Mappin, market sources say. Paoli is currently Mappin's director-superintendent. He assumed the post early this year.
FOLHA DE SAO PAULO
-- U.S. ATTACKS IRAQ
The United States attacked Iraq twice in less than 24 hours in response to Saddam Hussein's military incursion into Kurdish areas on Saturday.
-- OIL PRICES POST HIGHEST RISE SINCE 1990
Oil prices rose $23.50 a barrel in Singapore, its highest level since the Gulf War in 1990.
O GLOBO
-- JUSTICE ORDERS RIO STATE TO HELP AIDS VICTIM
For the first time in Rio de Janeiro state, a judge granted an injuction ordering Rio's Health department to provide drugs to Roberto Iglesias, 41 years-old, who has Aids.
-- SUMMERTIME BEGINS ON OCTOBER 6
Brazilian summertime will begin on October 6 in 12 states and the Federal District. The summertime, when clocks will be put forward one hour, will end on February 16, 1997.
-- Reuters has not verified these stories and cannot vouch for their accuracy.
-- Fatima Cristina, Sao Paulo newsroom, 55-11-2324411
